{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3544734,"name":"Gal","username":"GalDotan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/galdotan/{size}/201749_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-02T08:31:31.572Z","cooked":"

We have two Limelight 4s on our robot; about 40 minutes after powering on the robot, they reach 80 degrees, and a warning pops up.

Currently, they are mounted to ABS 3D prints. We will change the mount so both Limelights will connect to an aluminum plate together (with thermal paste). Then, a 3D print will connect the plate to the robot.

Should the plate have holes and be lightened? The logic says that making holes and pockets will increase the surface area and lead to faster cooling; on the other hand, it will remove some thermal mass.

This is a picture of the setup:

IMG-20250301-WA00281920×1080 277 KB

You probably want to keep a large area of thermal contact above all.
The option that requires the least amount of thinking is replacing your 3dp mounts with a machined piece of heatsink stock extrusion, like this.

As we say at work, the three modes of heat transfer are conduction, conduction, and conduction. Convection is basically pseudo science compared to forced air cooling.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-03-02T09:11:25.457Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":139,"readers_count":138,"score":32.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":493837,"topic_slug":"cooling-2-limelight-4s","display_username":"Troy Dietz","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"❤️ conflict-free COTS"},"post_url":"/t/cooling-2-limelight-4s/493837/2","custom_user_title":"❤️ conflict-free COTS","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3544744,"name":"Tristan Lall","username":"Tristan_Lall","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tristan_lall/{size}/97_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-02T10:24:35.957Z","cooked":"
GalDotan:

We have two Limelight 4s on our robot; about 40 minutes after powering on the robot, they reach 80 degrees, and a warning pops up.

Currently, they are mounted to ABS 3D prints. We will change the mount so both Limelights will connect to an aluminum plate together (with thermal paste). Then, a 3D print will connect the plate to the robot.

Should the plate have holes and be lightened? The logic says that making holes and pockets will increase the surface area and lead to faster cooling; on the other hand, it will remove some thermal mass.

Assuming you need to run the robot under whatever conditions, for this duration of time, and can’t solve this with a change in operating patterns, consider increasing convective heat transfer with a fan. It’s probably a faster solution than modifying the mounts.

The robot components will basically rise to and approach some steady-state temperature where the heat gain from the component and the heat loss to the surroundings (other robot parts and air) are balanced. A duration of 40 min is enough time for this situation to play out. Your goal should be, with only as much difficulty as necessary, to maximize the rate of heat lost which will lower this steady-state temperature.

I would start by installing some legal fans (see R501—they are actuators) that you have readily available, and seeing if that solves the issue. Fans (up to 10 W @ 12 V, and up to Ø120 mm), blowing on the front surfaces of the camera units will increase the amount of convective heat transfer significantly, and require almost no effort to install.

That’s legal for competition and legal for practice, so just leave them if it solves your problem without too much power consumption. It probably doesn’t matter very much which fan you choose: simply having any moving air will do a lot to keep the temperature reasonable.


Modifying the mount, or replacing it with a heatsink can work...but it isn't so easy to be specific without doing some calculations and considering the operating conditions more closely. If you want to become familiar with how the internal components of the Limelight transfer their heat to the different surfaces of their enclosure, and what fin spacing to use on heatsinks, and what the conductivity of different thermal interfaces (like paste between surfaces of unknown flatness) is, then this is absolutely feasible to engineer. But a fan is much simpler if you don't need to optimize and you just need it to work, fast.","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-03-02T10:24:35.957Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":110,"readers_count":109,"score":32.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":493837,"topic_slug":"cooling-2-limelight-4s","display_username":"Tristan Lall","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/cooling-2-limelight-4s/493837/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3544764,"name":"Alex","username":"aopalka","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/f9ae1b/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-02T11:59:21.763Z","cooked":"

I would say 40 minutes of usage is a really long time. I would suggest in practice you not run robots for that long continuously ( assuming based on the fact that it maintained that temp) you where in fact on continuously or hot swapped batteries as you went. It’s probably not great for other electronics such as motors as well.
